claims.text: HIV infects helper T-cells, which are central to the immune response.
claims.context: HIV's impact on the immune system's function.

claims.text: The immune system becomes exhausted and loses the ability to make new helper T-cells.
The body becomes immunodeficient, leading to AIDS.
There is no cure for HIV, and hidden reservoirs can rebound if treatment stops.
HIV uses reverse transcriptase to convert viral RNA into DNA.
HIV inserts its DNA into the host cell's genome.
Killer T cells and natural killer cells destroy infected cells directly.
Antiretroviral drugs can help the immune system recover from HIV.
HIV levels rise rapidly in the body after infection.
Anti-viral proteins called restriction factors work to shut down virus production.

claim_reports.claim_text: HIV infects helper T-cells, which are central to the immune response.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence consistently confirms that HIV infects CD4+ 'helper' T cells, which are essential for the immune response. Multiple high-reliability sources detail how this infection leads to the depletion of these cells, resulting in immunodeficiency and progression to AIDS.

supports.title: Follicular Helper T Cells Are Major Human Immunodeficiency Virus ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that HIV infects CD4+ 'helper' T cells, which are crucial for the immune response, leading to immunodeficiency as these cells are depleted.
supports.snippet: Follicular helper T cells support productive HIV-2 infection and are preferential viral targets in HIV-2-infected individuals. This is particularly relevant ...

supports.title: How Does HIV Bind to Our T Cells? New Study Reveals the Steps
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that HIV infects CD4+ 'helper' T cells, which are crucial for the immune response, leading to immunodeficiency as these cells are depleted.
supports.snippet: A new study reveals for the first time the steps through which human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) binds to the receptors on the membranes of T cells.

supports.title: Pathophysiology of CD4+ T-Cell Depletion in HIV-1 and HIV-2 ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that HIV infects and destroys CD4 T cells, also known as T helper cells, which are essential for the immune response. This infection leads to a gradual decrease in these immune cells, ultimately resulting in a weakened immune system and the progression to AIDS.
supports.snippet: The hall mark of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection is a gradual loss of CD4+ T-cells and imbalance in CD4+ T-cell homeostasis, with progressive ...

supports.title: The T-Cell Response to HIV - PMC - PubMed Central - NIH
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that HIV infects and destroys CD4 T cells, which are essential for coordinating the immune response, thereby supporting the claim that HIV infects helper T-cells central to the immune response.
supports.snippet: HIV infects and deletes CD4 + T cells that normally coordinate the adaptive T- and B-cell response to defend against intracellular pathogens.

supports.title: Editorial: CD4+ T cells in HIV: A Friend or a Foe? - Frontiers
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that HIV infects and destroys CD4 T cells, which are also known as T helper cells, and highlights their crucial role in the immune response. As HIV replicates within these cells, it leads to a decrease in their numbers, ultimately weakening the immune system.
supports.snippet: CD4+ T cell depletion: HIV infects and destroys CD4+ T cells during the replication process. If left untreated, HIV is the virus kills infected cells directly ...

claim_reports.claim_text: The immune system becomes exhausted and loses the ability to make new helper T-cells.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that the immune system becomes exhausted and loses the ability to produce new helper T-cells, particularly in the context of HIV infection. Multiple high-reliability sources detail how chronic infection leads to T-cell exhaustion and depletion of CD4+ helper T cells, which are essential for immune function.

supports.title: Revisiting Immune Exhaustion During HIV Infection - PMC
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses how HIV infection leads to the depletion of CD4+ helper T cells, which are crucial for the immune response, indicating that the immune system can become compromised and lose its ability to produce new helper T cells.
supports.snippet: A recently identified subset of T cells called Th17 cells also may also be compromised by immune activation during HIV infection [15]. While systemic ...

supports.title: HIV-Induced Changes in T Cell Signaling Pathways - PMC - NIH
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses T-cell exhaustion, which occurs due to chronic infection and leads to a significant loss of T-cell function, including the ability to produce new helper T-cells. This aligns with the claim that the immune system becomes exhausted and loses the ability to generate new helper T-cells.
supports.snippet: Infection with HIV usually results in chronic activation of the immune system, with profound quantitative and qualitative changes in the T cell compartment.

supports.title: Immune activation and exhaustion marker expression on T-cell ...
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses how HIV infection leads to the depletion of CD4+ helper T cells, which is critical for the immune system's function, suggesting that the immune system can become exhausted and lose its ability to produce new helper T cells.
supports.snippet: Immune activation and exhaustion markers correlate with HIV-1 reservoir size, as measured by HIV-1 DNA, in adult infections, providing measures ...

supports.title: Mucosal Regulatory T Cells and T Helper 17 Cells in HIV ... - Frontiers
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses T-cell exhaustion, which is characterized by a loss of function and proliferative potential in T cells, including helper T-cells, due to chronic antigen exposure. This aligns with the claim that the immune system becomes exhausted and loses the ability to produce new helper T-cells.
supports.snippet: HIV-1 infection is known to modulate TLR responses by altering TLR expression and activation levels, and regulating responses of innate immune cells to TLR ...

supports.title: The role of T regulatory cells in the immunopathogenesis of HIV
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses how HIV infection leads to the depletion of CD4+ helper T cells, which is a critical aspect of immune system exhaustion, suggesting that the immune system loses its ability to produce new helper T cells as a result of the infection.
supports.snippet: Tregs may accelerate disease progression by enhancing viral persistence and suppressing HIV-specific immune system responses leading to immune system exhaustion ...

claim_reports.claim_text: The body becomes immunodeficient, leading to AIDS.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence from multiple high-reliability sources, including HIV.gov and WHO, confirms that HIV infects and destroys CD4 T cells, leading to a weakened immune system and the progression to AIDS, thereby strongly supporting the claim that the body becomes immunodeficient, leading to AIDS.

supports.title: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS) - Clinical Info .HIV.gov
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that HIV infects and destroys CD4 T cells, leading to a weakened immune system and the progression to AIDS, which is characterized by immunodeficiency.
supports.snippet: To be diagnosed with AIDS, a person with HIV must have an AIDS-defining condition or have a CD4 count less than 200 cells/mm3 (regardless of whether the person ...

supports.title: Neurological Complications of HIV
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly states that HIV infects and destroys immune cells, specifically CD4 T cells, leading to a significant weakening of the immune system, which is defined as AIDS. This supports the claim that the body becomes immunodeficient, leading to AIDS.
supports.snippet: While HIV primarily affects the immune system, it can lead to a wide range of severe neurological disorders, particularly if HIV goes untreated and progresses ...

supports.title: About HIV - CDC
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence explains that HIV infects and destroys CD4 T cells, leading to a significant weakening of the immune system, which is characterized as AIDS. This aligns with the claim that the body becomes immunodeficient, leading to AIDS.
supports.snippet: Stage 3: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS). The most severe stage of HIV infection. People receive an AIDS diagnosis when their CD4 ...

supports.title: HIV and AIDS - World Health Organization (WHO)
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that HIV attacks the immune system, leading to immunodeficiency and the progression to AIDS if untreated.
supports.snippet: HIV targets the body's white blood cells, weakening the immune system. This makes it easier to get sick with diseases like tuberculosis, ...

supports.title: HIV Symptoms | AIDS - MedlinePlus
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence explains that HIV infects and destroys CD4 T cells, leading to a significant weakening of the immune system, which is characterized as AIDS. This directly supports the claim that the body becomes immunodeficient, leading to AIDS.
supports.snippet: AIDS stands for acquired immunodeficiency syndrome. It is the final stage of infection with HIV. It happens when the body's immune system is ...

claim_reports.claim_text: There is no cure for HIV, and hidden reservoirs can rebound if treatment stops.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that there is no cure for HIV and that hidden reservoirs can rebound if treatment stops. Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that while antiretroviral therapy can suppress the virus, it cannot eliminate latent reservoirs, leading to potential viral re-emergence upon treatment interruption.

supports.title: Eliminating HIV Reservoirs for a Cure: The Issue is in the Tissue - PMC
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that there is no cure for HIV, as treatment can suppress the virus but cannot eliminate the latent reservoirs that can cause the virus to rebound if treatment is stopped. It emphasizes the persistence of these reservoirs and the risk of viral re-emergence upon interruption of antiretroviral therapy.
supports.snippet: Tissue reservoirs are a critical source of rebounding HIV-1, which must be eradicated to achieve an HIV cure. The tissue distribution of potential therapeutics ...

supports.title: HIV's Cunning Strategy For Hiding in Our Body Finally Revealed
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that there is no cure for HIV, as it can hide in latent reservoirs and rebound if treatment is stopped, necessitating long-term antiretroviral therapy to manage the virus.
supports.snippet: HIV is infamous for its ability to hide in the human body for decades, typically requiring long-term treatment to prevent a rebound from ...

supports.title: HIV/AIDS - Diagnosis and treatment - Mayo Clinic
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that there is currently no cure for HIV, and it highlights that the virus can rebound if treatment is stopped, as seen in the majority of participants in the study who experienced a rebound after stopping ART.
supports.snippet: There's no cure for HIV / AIDS . Once you have the infection, your body can't get rid of it. But there are medicines that can control HIV and ...

supports.title: A5345 Provides Insights into Predictors of HIV Rebound - ACTG
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that while current antiretroviral therapy (ART) can manage HIV effectively, it does not cure the virus, and stopping treatment leads to viral rebound due to latent reservoirs.
supports.snippet: Study A5345 was designed to identify surrogate factors that can predict the timing when HIV may rebound.

mixed.title: Long-Term HIV Control: Could this Combination Therapy Be the Key?
mixed.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses a study showing that while there is no definitive cure for HIV, some participants were able to control the virus without long-term treatment, indicating that hidden reservoirs can rebound if treatment stops.
mixed.snippet: UCSF researchers have made strides toward an HIV cure, showing experimental immunotherapy can help control the virus without long-term ...

mixed.title: A seventh case of HIV cure reported at AIDS 2024
mixed.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses a recent study indicating that while there is no definitive cure for HIV, some participants were able to control the virus without ongoing treatment, suggesting that hidden reservoirs can rebound if treatment stops, as typically observed.
mixed.snippet: In 2007, Timothy Brown, the so-called first Berlin patient, was the first person to be considered cured of HIV.

claim_reports.claim_text: HIV uses reverse transcriptase to convert viral RNA into DNA.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that HIV uses reverse transcriptase to convert its RNA into DNA, as confirmed by multiple high-reliability sources including PubMed Central and Clinical Info from HIV.gov.

supports.title: HIV-1 Reverse Transcription - PMC - PubMed Central
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that HIV uses reverse transcriptase to convert its RNA genome into DNA, which is a fundamental aspect of retroviral replication.
supports.snippet: In HIV-1, the pbs is approximately 180 nucleotides from the 5′ end of genomic RNA. DNA synthesis creates an RNA–DNA duplex, which is a substrate for RNase H.

supports.title: Reverse Transcription - Clinical Info .HIV.gov
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that HIV uses reverse transcriptase to convert its RNA into DNA, as it explicitly states that HIV releases and uses reverse transcriptase to perform this conversion.
supports.snippet: Once inside a CD4 cell, HIV releases and uses reverse transcriptase (an HIV enzyme) to convert its genetic material—HIV RNA—into HIV DNA. The conversion of HIV ...

supports.title: Efficient HIV-1 in vitro reverse transcription: optimal capsid stability is ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that HIV-1 uses reverse transcriptase to convert its RNA genome into DNA, which is a critical step in the retroviral replication process.
supports.snippet: HIV-1 reverse transcriptase (RT) copies the viral genomic RNA into a double-stranded DNA, and HIV-1 integrase (IN) inserts the viral DNA into ...

supports.title: Structure of HIV-1 reverse transcriptase cleaving RNA in an ... - PNAS
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that HIV uses reverse transcriptase to convert its RNA genome into DNA, which is a fundamental process in retroviral replication.
supports.snippet: HIV-1 reverse transcriptase (RT) contains both DNA polymerase and RNase H activities to convert the viral genomic RNA to dsDNA in infected host ...

claim_reports.claim_text: HIV inserts its DNA into the host cell's genome.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that HIV inserts its DNA into the host cell's genome, with multiple high-reliability sources confirming the integration process as a key part of HIV's replication cycle.

supports.title: HIV DNA Integration - PMC - PubMed Central - NIH
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that HIV integrates its DNA into the host cell's genome as part of its replication cycle, specifically mentioning the integration of a DNA copy of the viral genome into a host cell chromosome.
supports.snippet: Integration of a DNA copy of the viral genome into a host cell chromosome is an essential step in the retroviral replication cycle.

supports.title: HIV: Cell Binding and Entry - PMC - NIH
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence describes the process of HIV entry into host cells, detailing how HIV delivers its genome into the host cell cytoplasm, which implies that HIV inserts its DNA into the host genome as part of its replication cycle.
supports.snippet: HIV uses a complex series of steps to deliver its genome into the host cell cytoplasm while simultaneously evading the host immune response.

supports.title: Early pandemic HIV-1 integration site preferences differ across ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that HIV-1 integrates its DNA into the host cell's genome, as it describes the process of reverse transcription and the formation of a pre-integration complex (PIC) that contains the viral DNA, which is then transported into the nucleus for integration.
supports.snippet: To evade immune detection and promote long-term persistence, HIV-1 often integrates into transcriptionally inactive regions of the host genome, ...

supports.title: HIV-1 capsid and viral DNA integration | mBio - ASM Journals
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that HIV-1 DNA is integrated into the host cell's genome after the nuclear entry step, indicating that the virus inserts its DNA into the host's genetic material.
supports.snippet: After the nuclear entry step, HIV-1 DNA is integrated into transcriptionally active regions of the host chromosomes (29, 32–34). HIV-1 IN is the ...

unclear.title: HIV Integration - an overview | ScienceDirect Topics
unclear.evidence_summary: Insertion of the viral genome into host cell chromatin by the viral integrase (IN) is a necessary step for the propagation of retroviruses.
unclear.snippet: Insertion of the viral genome into host cell chromatin by the viral integrase (IN) is a necessary step for the propagation of retroviruses.

claim_reports.claim_text: Killer T cells and natural killer cells destroy infected cells directly.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that killer T cells and natural killer cells directly destroy infected cells. High-reliability sources, such as the PubMed Central article, confirm that NK cells kill virally infected and cancerous cells directly, while other sources detail the direct action of both NK and cytotoxic T cells in eliminating infected cells.

supports.title: Natural Killer Cells and Cytotoxic T Cells - PubMed Central - NIH
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that natural killer (NK) cells directly kill virally infected and cancerous cells by releasing cytotoxic granules, which leads to the destruction of these target cells.
supports.snippet: They include cytotoxic T cells, which are the main cellular warriors of the adaptive immune system, specializing in killing virally infected or malignant cells.

supports.title: Comprehensive snapshots of natural killer cells functions, signaling ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that natural killer (NK) cells are known for their ability to kill virus-infected cells and tumor cells directly, supporting the claim about their function.
supports.snippet: Natural killer (NK) cells, initially identified for their rapid virus-infected and leukemia cell killing and tumor destruction, ...

supports.title: Cytotoxic T cells: Function, Production & Activation - Cleveland Clinic
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that both natural killer (NK) cells and cytotoxic T cells directly destroy infected cells. NK cells can kill cells that lack self-identifying markers, while cytotoxic T cells attack viruses when activated by antigens.
supports.snippet: Cytotoxic T cells attack viruses when activated by an antigen. Natural killer cells don't need activation to attack harmful cells. Cytotoxic T cells are part ...

supports.title: Natural Killer Cells | Dana-Farber Cancer Institute
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that both natural killer (NK) cells and killer T cells directly destroy infected cells. NK cells can kill cells that lack self-identifying markers and those emitting stress signals, while T cells require training to recognize and eliminate infected cells.
supports.snippet: Unlike T cells, which multiply profusely in order to eliminate infected or diseased cells, NK cells decline to proliferate when infused into ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Antiretroviral drugs can help the immune system recover from HIV.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence presents a mixed view on the claim that antiretroviral drugs help the immune system recover from HIV. While a JAMA article supports that ART can reduce immune activation and inflammation, a PMC article refutes the claim by stating that ART does not consistently improve immune recovery or CD4+ T-cell counts. Additionally, two other high-reliability sources indicate that while ART can temporarily improve immune function, these benefits may not be long-lasting.

refutes.title: Immune restoration after antiretroviral therapy: the pitfalls of hasty or ...
refutes.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that while antiretroviral therapy (ART) can lead to a reduction in immune activation and inflammation, it does not consistently improve immune recovery or CD4+ T-cell counts once viral suppression is achieved. Therefore, the claim that antiretroviral drugs help the immune system recover from HIV is not fully supported by the evidence provided.
refutes.snippet: Treatment intensification with additional anti-retroviral drugs, to improve CD4+ T-cell counts or modulate immune responses, has proven disappointing. Maraviroc ...

supports.title: Recovery of the Immune System With Antiretroviral Therapy
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that antiretroviral therapy (ART) can lead to a reduction in immune activation and inflammation, which are associated with HIV, suggesting that ART can help the immune system recover over time.
supports.snippet: The possibility of providing complete immune recovery after intense antiretroviral treatment also has implications for timing of such therapy. Current ...

mixed.title: Common HIV drugs increase a type of immunity in the gut
mixed.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that while antiretroviral drugs can temporarily improve immune function in individuals with HIV, this benefit is not long-lasting, as the immune system becomes dysfunctional over time despite treatment.
mixed.snippet: Drugs currently used to keep the HIV virus in check also cause immune-system changes that might make humans better able to resist viral infections.

mixed.title: Immune Activation and Inflammation Among People With HIV ...
mixed.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that antiretroviral therapy (ART) can lead to a decline in immune activation and inflammation among people with HIV, particularly when initiated early. However, it also states that modifying ART to further reduce immune activation after viral suppression is not supported by current data.
mixed.snippet: Switching or adding antiretroviral (ARV) drugs solely to reduce immune activation or inflammation is not recommended, except in a clinical trial ...

claim_reports.claim_text: HIV levels rise rapidly in the body after infection.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that HIV levels rise rapidly in the body after infection, with multiple high-reliability sources indicating that median viral loads can reach over 1,344,590 copies/mL within the first week of acute infection.

supports.title: Acute and Chronic HIV | HIV.gov
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that HIV levels are indeed high shortly after infection, with median viral loads reaching up to 1,344,590 copies/mL in the first week of acute infection, confirming that HIV levels rise rapidly after infection.
supports.snippet: HIV typically progresses through three stages: acute HIV infection, chronic HIV infection, and AIDS. This progression can happen over months or years.

supports.title: The Stages of HIV Infection | NIH - HIVinfo
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that during the acute stage of HIV infection, the virus multiplies rapidly and spreads throughout the body, leading to high levels of HIV in the blood.
supports.snippet: In the acute stage of infection, HIV multiplies rapidly and spreads throughout the body, attacking and destroying the infection-fighting CD4 ...

supports.title: Viral Loads Within 6 Weeks After Diagnosis of HIV Infection in Early ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that HIV viral loads are significantly higher during early (acute) infection compared to later stages, with median viral loads in the first week after diagnosis reaching as high as 1,344,590 copies/mL. This supports the claim that HIV levels rise rapidly in the body after infection.
supports.snippet: Early (including acute) HIV infection is associated with viral loads higher than those in later stages. This study aimed to examine the ...

supports.title: HIV DNA Set Point is Rapidly Established in Acute HIV Infection and ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that during the acute stage of HIV infection, the virus multiplies rapidly and spreads throughout the body, leading to a very high level of HIV in the blood, which supports the claim that HIV levels rise rapidly after infection.
supports.snippet: We show that HIV DNA in peripheral blood cells, a marker of the HIV reservoir size, establishes a set-point level during the first 6 weeks of infection.

mixed.title: About HIV - CDC
mixed.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that after HIV infection, individuals may experience flu-like symptoms within 2 to 4 weeks, suggesting a rapid response in the body, but it does not explicitly state that HIV levels rise rapidly in the body.
mixed.snippet: Most people have flu-like symptoms within 2 to 4 weeks after infection. Symptoms may last for a few days or several weeks. Having these symptoms ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Anti-viral proteins called restriction factors work to shut down virus production.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that anti-viral proteins, specifically host-encoded restriction factors like APOBEC3G, TRIM5α, and tetherin, effectively inhibit HIV-1 replication, thereby supporting the claim that they work to shut down virus production. While one source notes that HIV-1 can evade these factors, the overall evidence strongly supports the claim.

supports.title: Interactions between HIV proteins and host restriction factors
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses how host-encoded restriction factors, such as APOBEC3G, TRIM5α, and tetherin, inhibit HIV-1 replication, confirming the role of these proteins in shutting down virus production.
supports.snippet: Since these host proteins restrict HIV replication within cells, the host proteins are referred to as restriction factors, and participate in ...

supports.title: The Restriction Factors of Human Immunodeficiency Virus - PMC - NIH
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses how restriction factors, such as APOBEC3G, TRIM5α, and tetherin, serve as effective inhibitors of HIV-1 replication, confirming the claim that anti-viral proteins work to shut down virus production.
supports.snippet: Cellular proteins called “restriction factors” can serve as powerful blockades to HIV replication, but the virus possesses elaborate strategies to circumvent ...

supports.title: Interactions between HIV proteins and host restriction factors
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses how host-encoded restriction factors, such as APOBEC3G, TRIM5α, and tetherin, inhibit HIV-1 replication by interfering with specific steps in the virus's life cycle, thereby supporting the claim that anti-viral proteins work to shut down virus production.
supports.snippet: Host restriction factors inhibit infections by recognizing and interfering with specific steps in the life cycle of the virus responsible for ...

supports.title: The Restriction Factors of Human Immunodeficiency Virus
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that restriction factors are cellular proteins that effectively block HIV replication, supporting the claim that anti-viral proteins work to shut down virus production.
supports.snippet: Cellular proteins called “restriction factors” can serve as powerful blockades to HIV replication, but the virus possesses elaborate strategies to circumvent ...

mixed.title: HIV Restriction Factors and Mechanisms of Evasion - PMC
mixed.evidence_summary: The article discusses how host-encoded restriction factors, such as APOBEC3G, TRIM5α, and tetherin, inhibit HIV-1 replication, thereby supporting the claim that anti-viral proteins work to shut down virus production. However, it also notes that HIV-1 can evade these factors in human cells, complicating the overall effectiveness of these restriction factors.
mixed.snippet: The mechanisms for evasion from restriction factors are virus encoded and frequently involve HIV-1's regulatory/accessory proteins, namely, Vif, Nef, Vpu, and ...

transcript_data.text: when a virus winds up inside the body it's usually met with a furious onslaught from the immune system white blood cells immediately respond by releasing anti viral proteins attacking infected cells and recruiting backup usually this is enough but there's one virus that pushes the immune system beyond its limits HIV HIV infects one of the immune cells that is central to the body's response to pathogens the helper t-cell first the virus attaches and enters once inside the virus moves towards the nucleus along with its enzymes and genetic material one of these enzymes reverse transcriptase converts the viral RNA into a length of DNA which inserts into the cell's genome forcing the cell to spew out HIV proteins and genetic material to make new copies of the virus these new viruses escape the cell to infect others HIV levels rise rapidly in the body but the immune system doesn't move down without a fight inside infected cells anti viral proteins called restriction factors work to shut down virus production while others stop the virus from escaping the cell outside white blood cells called fiy cells produce neutralizing antibodies which bind to surface spikes on HIV particles and stop them entering healthy helper t-cells the greatest assault comes from killer T cells and natural killer cells which seek and destroy infected cells directly they release a protein called perforin which punches the infected cells allowing enzymes to be injected triggering Auto destruction for a while the defense holds and virus levels drop but HIV begins its counter-attack it disables the cell's antiviral proteins allowing new virus particles to leave the cell it also constantly mutates inside the cell to evade protection the immune system can't fight what it can't see eventually the immune system wears itself out killer T cells activated for too long exhausted and no longer respond to infection also the body loses the ability to make new helper t-cells to replace those killed in the fight and as a result their numbers plummet ultimately the body becomes immunodeficient and this condition is known as AIDS without treatment exposure to otherwise harmless microbes can be fatal we still have no way of eliminating HIV from the body completely there is no cure and hidden reservoirs of HIV will rebound if treatment stops but treatment with antiretroviral drugs can swing the balance allowing the immune system to recover from battle and live to fight another day [Music]
